awd_titl_txt: Integration of the Physical and Chemical Rock Properties, Structure, and Permeability of the San Andreas Fault, San Andreas Fault Observatory at Depth Borehole, California
awd_abstract_narration:
Ten years ago, about 40 m of whole rock core was collected from a depth of approximately 3 km across an actively creeping trace of the San Andreas Fault as part of Earthscope's San Andreas Fault Observatory at Depth Borehole. Every centimeter of SAFOD core sampled is extremely valuable and represents a rare view into an active plate boundary fault. The aim of the overall project is to provide more realistic constraints for earthquakes that occur along the San Andreas Fault and, more broadly, within active faults around the world through the examination of whole rock core samples and a synthesis of a variety of geological and geochemical data. Earthquakes occur as faults displace rocks in a response to stress within the Earth's crust. Before, during, and after an earthquake, the rocks record physical and chemical changes that are associated with this cycle. Earthquakes and associated hazards pose a significant risk to society that may result in loss of life, serious injuries, damage to infrastructure, and major economic impacts. This work contributes to the development of better constraints for earthquake ground-shaking and seismic safety hazard models for active fault systems. Working with undergraduate and graduate students, the project will create engaging and interactive learning modules for undergraduate non-majors and community-at-large events that contribute to the legacy of SAFOD and Earthscope data, and increase students' and the general public's awareness about the field of Earthquake Geology. 


This study is focused on the structure and composition of the San Andreas Fault at depth using the available range of cuttings, sidewall cores, whole-rock core, and downhole geophysical logging data from Earthscope's San Andreas Fault Observatory at Depth Borehole.  Specifically, the proposed research aims to: 

1)	Examine the mechanisms of deformation and slip localization, the grain- to fault-scale nature of fluid-rock interactions within the fault zone, and to determine the origin, nature, and roles of carbonaceous matter in the fault zone, testing the hypothesis that carbon-bearing fault rocks influence slip weakening and localization or serve as indicators for earthquake induced fluid migration.
2)	Couple new results on fault zone composition and structure with borehole-based data to determine the elastic properties of the fault zone, to examine the nature and significance of time-dependent chemical and physical fault zone processes, and to relate the material properties to key elastic parameters that affect the energy distributions in and near fault zones.  
3)	Synthesize and re-evaluate all published and accessible results by numerous research groups of the geology, geochemistry, and rock properties of SAFOD with our new results, to develop a predictive schematic model of fault zone structure and properties, which we will then relate to its elastic moduli. 
4)	Educate and mentor students to become competitive STEM Workforce members and effective science communicators through participation in research and in the development of interactive educational activities that contribute to the legacy of SAFOD and Earthscope data, and increasing students' and the general public's awareness of earthquake geology and seismic hazards. 

The SAFOD core provides an opportunity to rigorously examine in situ fault-rock samples in order to decipher the processes that influence seismic slip and aseismic creep. Systematic integration of microscopy and geochemistry enables us to understand structural diagenesis in dynamic, complex, and heterogeneous fault zones. Remnants of extensive alteration during fluid-rock interactions, and complex microstructural changes during deformation are difficult to resolve without diverse techniques at various scales. The proposed interdisciplinary approach using high-resolution microscopy, geochemistry, and evaluation of rock properties spans a wide range of scales and methods and will further contribute to our ability to decipher the physio-chemical processes (e.g., pressure, temperature, permeability, fluid composition and source) from processes associated with fluid migration at the microscopic scale in faults (e.g., thermal pressurization). 
The project will expand knowledge of the role of fluids during fault weakening, constrain the conditions associated with fluid migration at the micro-scale during the earthquake cycle, and determine the evolution of strength and slip behavior of major tectonic faults for seismic hazard assessment. The new and synthesized data sets will become accessible to the entire scientific community, as envisioned by the original Earthscope initiative and work towards answering one of Earthscope's outstanding questions identified in 2010: What is the slip distribution during earthquakes and what can we learn from heterogeneities about fault geometry and fault rheology?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Earthscope - San Andreas Fault Observatory at depth (SAFOD) Scientific borehole. SAFOD core provides a unique opportunity to examine in situ fault-rock samples from the grain- to fault-scale in order to decipher the processes that influence fault slip, deformation, and fluid-rock interactions within an actively creeping segment of the San Andreas fault zone. A primary goal of this project was to examine the structural and chemical composition of a new set of whole-rock core samples using an interdisciplinary approach consisting of X-ray diffraction, X-Ray fluorescence, high-resolution microscopy, and geochemical analyses. Highlights from this research include new geochemical analyses on 62 SAFOD core samples (Phases 1 and 3) and Raman Microscopy on carbonaceous-bearing slip surfaces. 

First, geochemical data from Phase 3 core reveal significant mineralogical and elemental variation between the main creeping fault zones, black ultrafine fault rocks, and surrounding mixed damage zone rocks. At the fine-scale, several geochemical subunits are observed with noticeable increases or decreases of minerals, oxides, and major and trace elements adjacent to, and/or within the main creeping fault strands. Our measurements support previous observations that show a pronounced decrease in Si with a corresponding increase in MgO within the creeping sections as compared to surrounding damage zone rocks. Increases in MgO are associated with the presence of serpentinite minerals that are only present within the creeping zones. Locally, clasts entrained within the creeping fault or damage zone rocks, significantly impact the overall geochemical signatures within a compositional unit. Black fault rock samples also exhibit a noticeable decrease in Si closest to a major creeping segment. This is explained by increases in CaO due to localized veining or the presence of reworked cataclasite clasts with abundant veining. In general, Si increases with increasing distance from slip surfaces. 

Next, through Raman Microscopy analyses, we discovered an increase in the degree of crystallinity of carbonaceous material along numerous thin slip surfaces and the main creeping strands of the San Andreas fault. We interpret these results to support either inferred strain gradients across the main creeping fault strands and localized slip surfaces or potential fluid-rock interactions. This is significant as carbon-bearing fault rocks may influence fault behavior and/or  serve as indicators for earthquake induced fluid migration. 

This expanded and more refined sample set of mineralogical, geochemical, and textural data of the SAFOD borehole, as it crosses an active creeping section of the San Andreas Fault, provides reference for constraints needed for earthquake hazards assessment models such as fault zone thickness, elastic properties, and fault geometries in the shallow crust. New geochemical data fills critical gaps in measurements within the existing SAFOD core sample database and reveals significant compositional variations and structural changes at small-scales within and across a dynamic, complex, and heterogeneous km-scale fault and fault-related damage zone. Integration of geological and geochemical data coupled with microscopy techniques expands our knowledge on the complex role of fluids and deformation during fault weakening and may also help to determine conditions associated with fluid migration at the micro-scale during the earthquake cycle. 

Broader impact results from research and collaborative interactions include: 1) education and mentorship of 6 students (3 M.S. and 3 undergraduates, with 5 identifying as women) in interdisciplinary geoscience research, laboratory work, and data analyses; 2) knowledge sharing related to the topic of Earthquake Geology, Scientific Drilling and SAFOD, and the Earthscope Legacy. Students worked closely with the PI to participate in several public education, scientific communication, and community outreach events, including a Native American student mentorship program; and 3) Two students worked with PI and USU Lecturer’s to develop a Fault Zone Drilling and SAFOD Learning Module that combines use of a short video (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7y6xxeXGLXI) with a summary handout and assignment questions (https://usu.box.com/s/0f9o4samz1zq83w7ezgibqgsxlpd0aoj) for USU non-geology majors and public educators. The module provides a view into shallow subsurface deformation processes and geophysical observations on the San Andreas fault and the analytical techniques used to investigate fault rocks.

 


Last Modified: 06/16/2023
Modified by: Kelly E Keighley Bradbury
